subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Is this group defunct?
msgSnippet: I like the idea of standardized spellings not because I think Read needs it, but rather that it could be used to easily create a pretty vast library of
messageBody:
I like the idea of "standardized" spellings not because I think Read needs it, but rather that it could be used to easily create a pretty vast library of literature in Read.  This website ( http://lingorado.com/ipa/ ) will generate IPA according to British or American pronunciation for example.  As I recall, OED is considered the "standard" for British English, Mirrian-Webster for American (and Gage-Collins for Canadian). 
If there are standardized libraries for text-to-speech, or other uses, it should be not insurmountable to use this to generate Read script automatically.  You could go a step further, and choose your output base on the desired accent as well.

I say this as someone who still hasn't read the "Call of Cthulhu" in the Yahoo Groups resources yet, never mind any of the other reading selections.

-tev


On 07/17/2017 02:42 PM, tvindy@... [Read_Alphabet] wrote:
 

This is an interesting question. One could make the argument that it would be better for people to write exactly how they speak rather than try to make their writing easily understandable to all speakers of English. After all, people don't normally alter their speech patterns to be more understandable, unless they speak a very strong and/or lesser-known dialect. It would be kind of neat to pick up a British or Australian novel written in Quickscript and be fully exposed to the author's pronunciation.

To prevent things from getting too extreme, a good compromise might be to restrict spelling to pronunciations listed in a specific dictionary. For example, I might choose to write using pronunciations listed in the Merriam-Webster dictionary. In that case, I would still have the freedom to choose from among whatever alternate pronunciations that dictionary includes. For example, I don't pronounce the th-sound in "clothes" or the c in "adjective," but Merriam-Webster lists my pronunciations. If I had a more idiosyncratic pronunciation that wasn't listed, then I would need to pick a more mainstream alternative. On thing I like about this dictionary method is that there is no need to compromise on spelling between different countries. A Brit could use the OED for his writing, and it would still be very intelligible to Americans, the same way Americans can watch the BBC and understand virtually everything, despite the differences in pronunciation.

I like the idea of "standardized" spellings not because I think Read 
needs it, but rather that it could be used to easily create a pretty 
vast library of literature in Read.  This website ( 
http://lingorado.com/ipa/ ) will generate IPA according to British or 
American pronunciation for example.  As I recall, OED is considered the 
"standard" for British English, Mirrian-Webster for American (and 
Gage-Collins for Canadian).
If there are standardized libraries for text-to-speech, or other uses, 
it should be not insurmountable to use this to generate Read script 
automatically.  You could go a step further, and choose your output base 
on the desired accent as well.

I say this as someone who still hasn't read the "Call of Cthulhu" in the 
Yahoo Groups resources yet, never mind any of the other reading selections.

-tev


On 07/17/2017 02:42 PM, tvindy@... [Read_Alphabet] wrote:
>
> This is an interesting question. One could make the argument that it 
> would be better for people to write exactly how they speak rather than 
> try to make their writing easily understandable to all speakers of 
> English. After all, people don't normally alter their speech patterns 
> to be more understandable, unless they speak a very strong and/or 
> lesser-known dialect. It would be kind of neat to pick up a British or 
> Australian novel written in Quickscript and be fully exposed to the 
> author's pronunciation.
>
> To prevent things from getting too extreme, a good compromise might be 
> to restrict spelling to pronunciations listed in a specific 
> dictionary. For example, I might choose to write using pronunciations 
> listed in the Merriam-Webster dictionary. In that case, I would still 
> have the freedom to choose from among whatever alternate 
> pronunciations that dictionary includes. For example, I don't 
> pronounce the th-sound in "clothes" or the c in "adjective," but 
> Merriam-Webster lists my pronunciations. If I had a more idiosyncratic 
> pronunciation that wasn't listed, then I would need to pick a more 
> mainstream alternative. On thing I like about this dictionary method 
> is that there is no need to compromise on spelling between different 
> countries. A Brit could use the OED for his writing, and it would 
> still be very intelligible to Americans, the same way Americans can 
> watch the BBC and understand virtually everything, despite the 
> differences in pronunciation.
>
>
